Many people think having a normal body weight means you are in good health.
And the federal government seems to feel the same way.
It's proposing new rules that would allow employers to punish workers for carrying too much body weight.
But as NPR's Angus Chen reports, a new study warns this could discriminate against millions of healthy Americans.
The proposed rules from the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission say it would be OK to charge workers 30 percent of their health insurance for being overweight or obese.
That's calculated using a formula called the body mass index, or BMI.
Some doctors are pushing back.
Picking and choosing BMI and charging people more, essentially based on a high BMI, that's a terrible idea.
That's Doctor Deborah Burnet, a professor of medicine at the University of Chicago.
She says BMI doesn't really say anything about your health.
A study published in the International Journal Of Obesity shows there are millions of Americans who are overweight or obese and have good metabolic and heart health.
Janet Tomiyama of UCLA is the lead author.
The 54 million Americans who aren't unhealthy but would be called unhealthy using the BMI standards, those people would be unfairly penalized.
Anyone with a BMI over 25 could face higher health costs, Burnet says.
